articles.headline: The Latest Flash Point Among Ukraine’s Allies Is Whether to Send F-16s
articles.snippet: The United States is resisting a European push for the powerful fighters. But will it relent, as it did before with tanks, rocket launchers and air defense missiles?
articles.abstract: The United States is resisting a European push for the powerful fighters. But will it relent, as it did before with tanks, rocket launchers and air defense missiles?
articles.lead_paragraph: A fresh push by Britain and the Netherlands to provide Ukraine with F-16 fighter planes has exposed the latest fault line among Western allies who have wrangled repeatedly over sending powerful weapons of war, once again pitting a reluctant United States against some of its closest European partners.
articles.byline: By Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: After Historic Primary in Philadelphia, a New Mayor Will Face Old Problems
articles.snippet: Cherelle Parker’s win in the Democratic primary is a sign of how the city has changed. But Philadelphia’s challenges remain deep and daunting.
articles.abstract: Cherelle Parker’s win in the Democratic primary is a sign of how the city has changed. But Philadelphia’s challenges remain deep and daunting.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The afternoon before Election Day, Jennifer Robinson, 41, was trying to manage her two small children in the quiet corner of a public library in a pocket of her city that had endured generations of abandonment. She was despondent about the state of Philadelphia, most of all about the crime, but she talked about the mayoral primary as if it had little bearing on any of it.

articles.headline: The Scramble to Take Over What Bed Bath & Beyond Left Behind
articles.snippet: Couples are racing to find new wedding registries while suppliers seek other customers and competing retailers pledge to accept that big blue coupon.
articles.abstract: Couples are racing to find new wedding registries while suppliers seek other customers and competing retailers pledge to accept that big blue coupon.
articles.lead_paragraph: Engaged couples are struggling to navigate Bed Bath & Beyond’s faltering wedding registry system. Suppliers are scrambling to cultivate new business partnerships. Landlords are quickly closing deals on leases for suddenly vacated big-box locations. On TikTok, a shopper’s daily trips to a Manhattan store have found a receptive audience.

articles.headline: Another Side of the A.I. Boom: Detecting What A.I. Makes
articles.snippet: More than a dozen companies have popped up to offer services aimed at identifying whether photos, text and videos are made by humans or machines.
articles.abstract: More than a dozen companies have popped up to offer services aimed at identifying whether photos, text and videos are made by humans or machines.
articles.lead_paragraph: Andrey Doronichev was alarmed last year when he saw a video on social media that appeared to show the president of Ukraine surrendering to Russia.
articles.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: In Battle Over A.I., Meta Decides to Give Away Its Crown Jewels
articles.snippet: The tech giant has publicly released its latest A.I. technology so people can build their own chatbots. Rivals like Google say that approach can be dangerous.
articles.abstract: The tech giant has publicly released its latest A.I. technology so people can build their own chatbots. Rivals like Google say that approach can be dangerous.
articles.lead_paragraph: In February, Meta made an unusual move in the rapidly evolving world of artificial intelligence: It decided to give away its A.I. crown jewels.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Another Casualty in Ukraine: Teenage Years
articles.snippet: In a battered Ukrainian city, the war has stolen the normal experiences of teenage life. The youths mostly use humor to deal with the ferocity of the fighting around them.
articles.abstract: In a battered Ukrainian city, the war has stolen the normal experiences of teenage life. The youths mostly use humor to deal with the ferocity of the fighting around them.
articles.lead_paragraph: The yawning crater, carved by a Russian missile strike and flooded with water, cut a jagged path through the middle of a city street. The small clique of teenagers passing by found it funny.

articles.headline: Extremism Finds Fertile Ground in Chat Rooms for Gamers
articles.snippet: In the past year, about half the people who played online multiplayer games in the world’s major gaming markets encountered extremist statements, a new study found.
articles.abstract: In the past year, about half the people who played online multiplayer games in the world’s major gaming markets encountered extremist statements, a new study found.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are rules people must agree to before joining Unloved, a private discussion group on Discord, the messaging service popular among players of video games. One rule: “Do not respect women.”
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Kellen Browning

articles.headline: Supreme Court Won’t Hold Tech Companies Liable for User Posts
articles.snippet: The justices ruled in one case that a law allowing suits for aiding terrorism did not apply to the ordinary activities of social media companies.
articles.abstract: The justices ruled in one case that a law allowing suits for aiding terrorism did not apply to the ordinary activities of social media companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court handed twin victories to technology platforms on Thursday by declining in two cases to hold them liable for content posted by their users.
